A structural decomposition measure that estimates the relative importance of predetermined factors versus individual effort in generating dynastic income mobility and, by extension, income inequality/incentive costs.

No standard empirical measure is used; rather, the paper employs a three‐period stochastic overlapping generations model to structurally analyze mobility and its political equilibrium implications.

Instead, it discusses estimating the joint effect of sociodemographic shifts (namely rising marital homogamy in human capital and changes in female labor supply) on long‐term income dynamics and intergenerational mobility, which does not fall neatly into the conventional categories and is best classified as ‘Others’

Qualitative descriptive assessment of social mobility (no formal quantitative measure)

The paper appears to use regression‐based measures. It reports the proportion of variance in wage income explained by class (i.e. an R-squared–type statistic) and also observes mobility through differences in class positions between fathers and children.

The study uses a multigenerational approach—examining class status transmission (notably noting that those with impoverished grandparents remain disadvantaged)—which fits under multigenerational measures. It also reports a Gini coefficient for land distribution, although for mobility the focus is on class continuity across generations.
Non‐parametric adjusted regression approach expressing interactions as nonlinear marginal effects

The paper does not calculate a traditional quantitative mobility metric. Instead, it offers a qualitative examination of parental investments and the role of kin financial transfers in supporting expenditures (e.g., education, enrichment) during economic hardship.

The paper employs regression‐based estimation methods—estimating, for example, the earnings‐experience profile and the responsiveness of wages to changes in educational supply—to assess intergenerational mobility effects. The paper does not use a standard mobility measure but instead develops a theoretical model that characterizes equilibrium network structures. In this model, stability is determined by coalitions (restricted by a network distance k), intermediation decay in network benefits, and the degree of intergenerational transmission of wealth. Thus, the measure falls under ‘Others’ as it is a network‐equilibrium based approach rather than one of the conventional mobility measures.
Pareto distribution (stationary wealth distribution derived from a structural model)
